msContents.summary:
A multi-text (possibly composite?) manuscript containing following works on traditional medicine, i.e.:
TheÑāṉaveṭṭiyāṉ kaṟpamuṟai aṟuva? viruttam (enlisted on the title page as: "Kaṟpamuṟai", "Recipes for panacea"), a medical text ascribed to author named "Veṭṭiyāṉ", in 61 verses (f1r-7r) (U2).
TheKaruvūrār palatiraṭṭu muṉṉūṟu ("Karuvūrār palatiraṭṭu", "Anthology of Karuvūrār"), a medical text ascribed to siddhar Karuvūrār, in 229 verses (marginal title suggests, that the original text consisted of approx. 300 verses, so the text in the manuscript seems to be incomplete), f8r-38r (U3).
TheAkasttiyar tirunaṭaṉa cūsttiram ("Tirunaṭaṉa cūttiram", "Treatise on the Sacred Dance"), a text on medicine and yoga ascribed to siddhar Akasttiyar, in 48 verses (f1r- 7v [f39r -45v]) (U4).
ThePañcarattiṉa pūpati māttirai ("Pañcarattiṉa pūpati mālai", "Royal garland of the five jewels" ), a medical text containing several pratical recpies (f1-5v [f46r-50v]) (U5).
Vayittiya cillaṟai ("Fragments on medicine"), a text which consists of several medical recipes (f1r-4r [51r-54r]) (U6).

origin.origDate: No internal date. Dated neither by Vinson (1868) nor by Cabaton (1912).

listBibl.bibl: Cabaton, Antoine (1912). Catalogue sommaire des manuscrits indiens, indo-chinois & malayo-polynésiens. Bibliothèque nationale. Département des manuscrits. Paris: E. Leroux. — See p. 25, n0. 134..

Vinson, Julien (1868). Manuscrits tamouls. Proofreadings of the catalogue for Tamoul 1-204 (old shelfmark). Printed by the atelier oriental de l’Imprimerie nationale. BnF “4-IMPROR-77 (B)”. — See p. 36, no. 134. — The same proofreadings with black ink handwritten corrections are found in Vinson et al. (1866-, f1-f49).

encodingDesc.p: Transliteration conventions ― Unmarked puḷḷi, ō, and ē restored. Uppercase for initial vowels (in excerpts only). ― Abbreviations ― c = column, f = folio, lm = left margin, lc = left column, rc = right column, 1c = first column, 2c = second column, 3c = third column, r = recto, rm = right margin, U = unit (codicological and/or textual), v = verso.
